column1: Support hyperledger fabric 1.0 ￼
column37:
We already support 0.6 now.

Cello will support multiple blockchain types including fabric 1.0 and others.

column1: rest server: update api definitions yml files.
column37: update api definitions yaml files.

column1: engine: support advanced scheduling
column37: support advanced scheduling
column138:
05/Feb/18 1:28 PM;baohua;Currently, when do fillup, cello randomly select supported network types.

May support more scheduling rules.;;;

column1: Support kubernetes as the underly platform
column37:
Currently we support Docker and Swarm.

Need to support more like k8s.

This may require a decouple from underly platforms.
column101: Let Cello support run fabric on top of k8s
column139:
06/Jun/17 11:41 AM;baohua;I suppose it is not very difficult to simply run fabric containers on top of k8s, as k8s already has provided many useful features to container services, like the deployment, daemonset, controllers..

The basic idea is to write some driver agent in Cello, to handle the requests from dashboard, and convert them to the underly platform (e.g., swarm, k8s) API calls.

Besides, there will be states maintained in Cello, like the blockchain status.

Key challenges may include:
 # Choose appropriate overlay network in k8s, e.g., flannel or calico, or the merging canal. (MUST). Hence we should provide some best-practice k8s config.
 # Let fabric start up chaincode container through k8s's API, which requires the support from fabric code. (BETTER TO HAVE)
 # Storage support. (FUTURE);;;
column141:
25/Jun/17 2:25 PM;chawlanikhil24;Fabric 0.6 is ready to run on top of kubernetes. I've prepared that .yaml files which will deploy, 
 # hyperledger-membersrvc
 # hyperledger-cli
 # hyperledger-root
 # hyperledger-peer1
 # hyperledger-peer2
 # hyperledger-peer3

These files can be found at this  [link|https://github.com/chawlanikhil24/hyperledger-fabric-k8s] . 

Currently, I am using weave-net for kubernetes overlay network. Will consider flannel or canal later, once the K8s cluster is in a running state.

Now, we've a cli-pod which is linked with peers and root, so whatever API instructions Cello need to provide, Cli will be endpoint for those instructions.

Please do share some reviews and problems in deploying the cluster. ;;;
column143:
26/Jun/17 2:38 PM;chawlanikhil24;Yupp, I am on the job of fabric-1.0 over kubernetes.

Also, making a patchset to demo support fabric-0.6 over K8s.;;;
column146:
28/Jun/17 8:45 PM;chawlanikhil24;Finally I've created the CLUSTER of Fabric 1.0 , using the reference files in [yeasy|https://github.com/yeasy/docker-compose-files/tree/master/hyperledger/1.0] files.   

The K8s manifests can be found at this [link|https://github.com/chawlanikhil24/hyperledger-fabric-k8s] .

Few problems are still there, like, when I ran the commands mentioned in this [docs|https://github.com/yeasy/docker-compose-files/blob/master/hyperledger/1.0/docs/docker-compose-1peer-usage.md] , the following is generated in the cli-container. The image of the logs is attached in the comment.

!logs-fabric-cli.png!;;;
column147: 28/Jun/17 8:57 PM;baohua;Nice progress, and feel free to ref to the doc at https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/examples/e2e_cli/end-to-end.rst;;;
column149:
03/Jul/17 10:59 AM;baohua;In k8s, it supports service name like srv1.local.com in dns record?

see https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/services-networking/dns-pod-service/.;;;
column152: 28/Jul/17 3:38 PM;Luke_Chen;How about use namespaces(k8s) to maintain organizations(Fabric) ?  like we have members such as peers, cli and ca belong to org1.example.com, so we binding all the k8s resources(pods, service, PV .etc) of those members  into namespace “org1.example.com”, however, due to k8s doesn't support '.' and capitalized letter,  we  need to change  "org1.example.com" to "org1-example-com"   ;;;
column153:
28/Jul/17 3:43 PM;baohua;[~Luke_Chen] technically, we can do that, however, can u elaborate the pros/cons for the proposal?

In fabric, org is more like some membership group sharing same trust base; while namespace in k8s is to isolate resources. I'm not sure if it's natural to map them together.;;;
column154: 28/Jul/17 3:58 PM;Luke_Chen;Sure, I am working on it;;;

column1: Migrate 0.6 code to support version as parameter
support custom theme for dashboard
column37:
From a long-term perspective, whether need to be changed to django framework.Because The django framework has achieved a lot of wheels. Flask as a lightweight lightweight framework, in the future, may need to achieve feature functions, but these functions may have been implemented in the django, the code may not be as efficient as Django.
      In openstack horizon, they use theme feature of Django for custom theme path. So I think we need some discussion about the web service framework.

column1: Change the watchdog implementation
column37: The current implementation of watchdog is a separate process of multi-threaded work, is not high-availability procedures. So I think may be it can be replaced by celery to increase the procedures for high availability.

column1: Cello Dashboard Issue

All steps seems to be fine except the docker cello-restserver, cello-dashboard and cello-watchdog are showing as restarting even after waiting for hours.

Logs for dashboard also attached below.

column147:
06/Feb/17 8:42 PM;baohua;The reason is the docker-compose python lib has changes in its new version.

Since 1.10.0, there will be docker client error with docker-compose python lib.

```
from docker import Client
```

Will fix soon.;;;

column1: Cello - Deployment Clarifications
column37:
Please note that there is no documentation of how to deploy a chaincode to the WORKER Node. and get it auto replicated in multiple nodes.
Seems there is some issue with my understanding and the available docs are not giving a clear picture.
So this is what I did
1. Setup the 4 node setup

column1: Add tutorial for operation
column37:
From Daniel Vielvoye <dvielvoye@gmail.com>

Hello, 

I'm trying Cello and would like to prepare a presentation to our management with the idea to promote the idea of "blockchain platform as a Service" in our community cloud environment. After installing cello (1 master and 2 workers) , I'm now facing the need to have some demo to confirm the setup works and demonstrate how this works . 
 
it would be nice to have a ready to deploy blockchain to deploy on Cello . This would allow to present a running experience of Cello and will also define the guideline to effectively deploy blockchains over Cello .(ideally such "demo-chain" would be available with the different blockchain engines supported by Cello. By the way a good instructions set will also be required on how to deploy code on the chain created in Cello

as a next step , I would like to be able to POC with a context meaningful  (so our business people can "see" what it can be used for) . Here I would like to have a t utorial : a step by step guide to have a newbie able to develop a basic application using a blockchain on Cello . This could be a Go or Java step by step development and deployment guide (a cookbook style) to write and demo a predefined ,limited scope, "project".

Are such demo/tutorial available for Cello ?

21/May/17 4:55 PM;DaVi;after review it seems that the following change in src/agent/docker/docker_swarm.py will do the detected work correctly . 

server_swarm_cluster = client.info()['Swarm']['Cluster']['ID']
if server_version.startswith('swarm') or server_swarm_cluster != '':

BUT it must be noted that :
 * the cello dashboard does not make difference between single or swarm and does report both as "DOCKER" in type 
 * Deployment of a chain on swarm machine is handled on the single node not on the swarm cluster (on swarm a docker-compose will not do , it should be handled through docker stack deploy (with a docker-compose V3 file) )

I'm fixing the detection the the complete deployment over swarm cluster (eventually to be targeted for Fabric 1.0 ?)

column1: Resolve licensing issues discovered by Fossology scan
column37:
Cello source was scanned using Fossology to determine license for files contained in the following repositories
 * [http://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/cello]
 * [http://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/cello-analytics]

From the Hyperledger Charter ([https://www.hyperledger.org/about/charter)] Section 13, all files that are included in Hyperledger projects should either be licensed with the Apache License, Version 2.0 for source code or Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License for documentation.  There are a number of files in the Cello source base that do not meet these requirements.  See the attached file for results. 

The highest priority should be the three files that come from a proprietary component called Highcharts.  These are not open source files and *must* be replaced.

The files listed under Attribution, Other/Unknown, and No License Found need to be resolved. For the Attribution and Other/Unknown, these appear to be tied to the themes and user dashboard. These should be replaced with code meeting the Apache 2.0 license.

For the files listed as No License Found, we should first check with the original contributors to make sure that they can contain an Apache 2.0 license (for source code) or a Creative Commons with Attribution 4.0 license (for documentation). Once this has been verified, the editable files must be annotated with the correct license text and/or the SPDX short identifiers (see  [https://spdx.org/sites/cpstandard/files/pages/files/using_spdx_license_list_short_identifiers.pdf]).
 For binary files, a license.txt file should be included in the directory calling out the file types and the associated license.

Any files that are not covered by Apache 2.0 or CC by 4.0 that need to remain with the project will need to go through an exception process with the governing board.
column138: 12/Jun/17 12:37 PM;baohua;Thanks, we need to update to add license headers.;;;
column139:
28/Aug/17 11:40 PM;baohua;[~tkuhrt] We've update the code with adding license headers, could u help re-check if there's missed ones?

Thanks!;;;
column140: 31/Oct/17 4:14 AM;tkuhrt;[~baohua] : I have attached the latest results from October scan. It looks like there are still a number of missing licenses headers and the highcharts files still exist. I can open a separate ticket for this. Let me know.;;;
column141:
31/Oct/17 11:00 AM;baohua;[~tkuhrt], pls help do that, we will follow to fix.

Thanks!;;;

column1: Update fabric 1.0 compose files
column37:
We need to add some compose template to support fabric 1.0.

 

This can be found at fabric e2e example, but need to update to latest one, to support a quick bootup with a 2-org-4-peer network topology.

column1: Enable starting a 2-org-4-peer fabric 1.0 network on worker node
column37:
Redesign the existing code (which is hardcoded to support fabric v0.6) to support multiple types of blockchain network, from fabric 1.0 to others.

 

And implement the fabric 1.0 running on worker node, i.e. users can start/stop a fabric 1.0 network (with exampled 2-org-4-peer config) at the worker node through RESTful API or dashboard.

column144:
11/Jul/17 3:55 PM;chawlanikhil24;[~qiang0723] , I made your suggested changes, but the issue at the beginning is with , orderer-service, which is demanding for the tls handshake and it is not being successfully executed. I am attaching the pic of the container log, I disables the tls handshake from the cli-container but, I can't disable tls-handshake on orderer-service mannually. If I am going correct, then for running chain code, we need to disable this tls-handshake and then proceed. 

 

!image-2017-07-11-12-25-25-492.png!;;;
column145:
11/Jul/17 4:07 PM;chawlanikhil24;When I enabled the "TLS_HANDSHAKE" from the fabric-cli pod. then 

```

2017-07-11 07:05:33.725 UTC [msp] GetLocalMSP -> DEBU 005 Returning existing local MSP
2017-07-11 07:05:33.725 UTC [msp] GetDefaultSigningIdentity -> DEBU 006 Obtaining default signing identity
2017-07-11 07:05:33.728 UTC [grpc] Printf -> DEBU 007 Failed to dial orderer-service:7050: connection error: desc = "transport: authentic
ation handshake failed: x509: certificate is valid for orderer.example.com, orderer, not orderer-service"; please retry.
Error: Error connecting due to rpc error: code = Internal desc = connection error: desc = "transport: authentication handshake failed: x
509: certificate is valid for orderer.example.com, orderer, not orderer-service"

```

configtx.yaml allows me to create certs, in name-format: orderer.example.com not orderer-service, somehow we need to fix this;;;
column148: 11/Jul/17 5:17 PM;qiang0723;[~chawlanikhil24] How can I repeat your steps, refer to [https://github.com/chawlanikhil24/hyperledger-fabric-k8s/tree/master/fabric-1.0] ?;;;
column149:
11/Jul/17 5:44 PM;chawlanikhil24;I followed the same steps, mentioned in [https://github.com/chawlanikhil24/hyperledger-fabric-k8s/blob/master/fabric-1.0/README.md] . 

I used minikube+weavenet .;;;
column150: 12/Jul/17 10:48 AM;grapebaba;IMO, we don't need follow e2e_cli example. We need create tls certs using domain name which k8s used for peer service, orderer service;;;
column151:
13/Jul/17 3:25 PM;chawlanikhil24;After Disabling all the TLS handshakes, and debugging of scripts

I've reached till "creating the channel" from scripts/initialize.sh

Now, the only error persisting is, peer not joining the channel ..

error from the logs is:
{code:java}
2017-07-13 06:24:32.986 UTC [msp] GetDefaultSigningIdentity -> DEBU 006 Obtaining default signing identity
2017-07-13 06:24:32.986 UTC [channelCmd] InitCmdFactory -> INFO 007 Endorser and orderer connections initialized
2017-07-13 06:24:32.987 UTC [msp/identity] Sign -> DEBU 008 Sign: plaintext: 0A8A070A5C08011A0C08A0A49CCB0510...EDF55FE0E72A1A080A000A000A000A00 
2017-07-13 06:24:32.987 UTC [msp/identity] Sign -> DEBU 009 Sign: digest: D5DE97D82BA14CDBEFF7AF3E1034194576B6AD908669FF1E413BC3CEAB6EADF9 
Error: proposal failed (err: rpc error: code = Unimplemented desc = unknown service protos.Endorser)

{code}
I assume, if we rectify this ASAP, then fabric-1.0 will be running on top of K8s.;;;
column152:
22/Jul/17 2:00 PM;chawlanikhil24;The last error has been debugged. The error was due to a bug of Kubernetes and the CNI i was using is weave.net . After updating to Kubernetes 1.7.1 and lates version of "Flannel", solved the issue of peer joining. As well as chaincode has been installed on the peers. 

The only Issue that persists is "chaincode container creation" from inside of a kubernetes Pod. Working on it, and soon it will be fixed. The 2 ways I can think of :
 # Sharing the docker socket of host machine with the peer pod containers, and then create container on machine using the same socket.
 # Linking the peer container with kubernetes DNS pod and finding a way to deploy Chaincode Pod.;;;

column1: Policy Enforcement from Cello dashboard
column37:
As a  blockchain network administrator  ,using the  graphical user interface of "policy manager", I should be able to create and enforce policies for the organizations/users of my blockchain network and  monitor the same , so that I could adhere to the business and compliance rules .

 

 

*Note*: We may have to create a policy manager app/module  . Potentially we need to integrate the same to cello . Policy management is an area by its own and involves  actions such as policy creation , enforcement, monitoring  and updation . Another option is to have a standalone policy manager , because some cases policies may be independent of  deployment .
column138: 26/Jul/17 6:01 PM;baohua;I do believe this is an exciting feature, and would welcome any volunteer who wanna start some design discussions. Thanks!;;;

column1: Debugging of Manifests to run the Chaincode Container
column37:
Still, there is an issue persisting is, chaincode container image has been created, but due to bugs, en error is persisting "no such image", after running 

```
 bash scripts/initialize.sh
 ```

on the fabric-cli . 

Also, Chaincode Ccontainer to Pod communication also needs fixes .
column139:
29/Jul/17 6:07 AM;chawlanikhil24;I'll be looking forward to involve Kubernetes-Ingress to create a path from chaincode container to kube-dns and then finally to peer-pods. 

docker-chaincode-container -> Ingress -> KubeDns -> peerpod

This will probably maintain stability until the time we are able to directly manipulate the chaincode-container to Kube-Dns. 

 ;;;
column140: 13/Aug/17 3:34 PM;chawlanikhil24;Since, as per my last comment, Ingress didn't work out, because docker needs a DNS ip, instead of a DNS name which is provided by Ingress. So, plan dropped for Ingress and decided to expose the Kube-dns on a nodeport and then create an ngnix proxy to operate Kube-DNS on port 53;;;

column1: Use vue to overwrite basic theme
column37: Want to use vue to overwrite basic theme, and change bootstrap theme. Whether to use webpack to build js for spa or directly write script in html template for multi html. And want to use new theme such as muse-ui instead of boot strap. Any suggestions?
column138: 04/Aug/17 11:59 AM;hightall;I think muse-ui is like material ui, and can fit to any device, and looks better than bootstrap. If will change current theme, I think it's better that we do it at early stages.;;;
column139: 04/Aug/17 12:00 PM;hightall;[~baohua] do you have any suggestions ?;;;
column140: 04/Aug/17 12:04 PM;hightall;This is Muse-UI link http://www.muse-ui.org/#/index;;;
column141: 04/Aug/17 12:08 PM;baohua;Cool, can u help elaborate the advantage of changing to Muse-UI?;;;
column142:
04/Aug/17 12:18 PM;hightall;My personal understanding:
1. This UI library is Encapsulated components for vue, so it's very easy for development, at least better than currently based on jquery. And document is very detailed.
2. If we want to change to SPA, it's will very quickly to use this library.
3. Better user experience.
4. Currently is also very hot font-end frame, and Get started quickly. For better development later, I think we need change front-end frame.;;;
column143:
15/Aug/17 8:38 AM;baohua;Thanks and is muse-UI limit to only support VUE?

I mean can it work with other frameworks comparing with Bootstrap?;;;
column144: 15/Aug/17 10:06 AM;hightall;It imitate material ui, if use other frameworks, e.g. react & angular we can use origin material ui library. Because material ui didn't provide Vue library.;;;
column145: 15/Aug/17 10:14 PM;baohua;Seems material UI can support more types of JS frameworks? Hence would we choose it instead of the muse one?;;;
column146: 15/Aug/17 10:32 PM;hightall;I tried to find the official version of Vue for material ui, but unfortunately did not find it, so find this muse to replace the material ui, and it have the most stars on github.;;;

column1: Enhance Cello to support Fabric on top of vSphere
column37:
Currently, Cello supports Docker and Swarm as the deployment platform. For a majority enterprise users, they usually already have vSphere as the virtual infrastructure in their data center. It is very convenient for them if Fabric could be deployed on vSphere directly.

We will create a vSphere Driver of Cello for this purpose.
column138:
15/Aug/17 8:33 AM;baohua;+1, this will let Cello support more infrastructure types.

Would suggest to finish into several steps:

1. Design the driver to call vsphere APIs.
2. Integrate the driver into the core engine.
3. Modify the dashboard to let people can choose vsphere as host type.

Feel free to create sub-tasks for the feature, thanks!;;;

column1: fail to create chain cluster on swarm hosts
column37:
when i create a host at Dashboard, the process is:

POST /host ->

host_create():src/resources/host_api.py ->

HostHandler.create():src/modules/host.py ->

DockerHost.create():src/agent/docker/host.py ->

But, there's a conflict args assign through the routine, in host_create, we do not provide a host_type for HostHandler.create() so it use the default value WORKER_TYPES[0] (which is "docker") and serialize it to db, but in the DockerHost.create(), we use detect_daemon_type() to get the docker host type(which now is "swarm") and setup the host network (for swarm it's a overlay network not the bridge for docker) but do not update the host_type in the db

 

IMO, it's better to united all create method with the same parameter list so that we can get the unified behavior

column1: Enhance support for MacOS users.
column37:
Currently, the scripts/master_node/setup.sh does not recognize Mac OS, Mac OS will be classified as "Unknown Distribution", and go through normal flow. That will include several pitfall of setup-master goal.
 #  the docker and pip installation will be skipped.
 # MacOS(Sierra 10.12.6) doesn't have a "usermod" command, so "sudo usermod -aG docker $\{USER}" will always fail and  {color:#ff0000}the process continues and didn't indicate failure in the middle.{color}
 # The MacOS(Sierra 10.12.6) does not  create a group for a user by default.  The "&& sudo chown -R $\{USER}:$\{USER} $\{DB_DIR}" is assuming there is a same name group for current user, it will fail if current user don't manually create a same name group. {color:#ff0000}The process continues and didn't indicate failure in the middle.{color} User then will see Mongo mount failure while the cello service is up, and don't know why.

And the 4th problem of Cello about mac is that document has several places mentioning user should configure the firewall by "{{sysctl -w net.ipv4.ip_forward=1}}". Actually, MacOS don't have this  either, the equal thing should be "sudo sysctl -w net.inet.ip.forwarding=1". This issue will also cause false alert in "setup-worker" process.

column1: Resolve remaining licensing issues discovered by Fossology scan
column37:
Hyperledger Cello source from October 12, 2017 was scanned using Fossology to determine license for files contained in the following repositories
 * [https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/cello]

 * [https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/cello-analytics]

 * [https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/cello-k8s-operator]

From the Hyperledger Charter ([https://www.hyperledger.org/about/charter)] Section 13, all files that are included in Hyperledger projects should either be licensed with the Apache License, Version 2.0 for source code or Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License for documentation.  There are a few files in the Cello source base that do not meet these requirements.  See the attached file for results. 

The files listed under Attribution and No License Found need to be resolved. For the Attribution tab, these files should be replaced with code meeting the Apache 2.0 license. If they cannot be, we need to understand why so that we can get governing board exception for these files.

For the files listed as No License Found, we should first check with the original contributors to make sure that they can contain an Apache 2.0 license (for source code) or a Creative Commons with Attribution 4.0 license (for documentation). Once this has been verified, the editable files must be annotated with the correct license text and/or the SPDX short identifiers (see  [https://spdx.org/sites/cpstandard/files/pages/files/using_spdx_license_list_short_identifiers.pdf]). For binary files, a license.txt file should be included in the directory calling out the file types and the associated license.

Any files that are not covered by Apache 2.0 or CC by 4.0 that need to remain with the project will need to go through an exception process with the governing board.

column1: Cello Ansible - Kafka crashing
column37:
After provisioning a new AWS cluster with the Ansible scripts, all the docker containers were running except Kafka, which was rebooting.

The docker logs shows that it was unable to connect to the zookeepers nodes.
Further debugging indicated that all inter-node communication was broken. Not just zookeeper.
Log into a container, and try to ping another container on a different host. The ping fails.

Ultimately, the explanation is here https://docs.docker.com/engine/userguide/networking/default_network/container-communication/#container-communication-between-hosts

"""
Container communication between hosts
For security reasons, Docker configures the iptables rules to prevent containers from forwarding traffic from outside the host machine, on Linux hosts. Docker sets the default policy of the FORWARD chain to DROP.
To override this default behavior you can manually change the default policy:
$ sudo iptables -P FORWARD ACCEPT
The iptables settings are lost when the system reboots. If you want the change to be permanent, refer to your Linux distribution’s documentation.
"""

In order to make the change permanent I have experimented with iptables-persistent, netfilter-persistent, and ufw. However, if Docker launches after those services it may still overwrite iptables -P FORWARD DROP.

systemd is customizable in terms of dependencies. The solution could be to create a simple systemd oneshot service, which runs _after_ the docker daemon is launched. And the oneshot service will run:

$ sudo iptables -P FORWARD ACCEPT
column38: Ubuntu 16.04, Cello Ansible v0.7, Docker 1.13.1
column138:
16/Nov/17 10:32 PM;sdarwin;More info:
https://github.com/moby/moby/pull/28257
https://github.com/moby/moby/issues/14041
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/40182

"Might be considered too much of a workaround and I haven't tested it fully but it might be possible to add a ExecStartPost directive to the systemd unit file to execute iptables -P FORWARD ACCEPT after Docker starts to automatically set it.";;;
column139: 29/Nov/17 10:47 PM;tongliofcary;[~sdarwin] can you share steps that you followed to stand up your cluster? Also your configuration files. Dealing with iptables is done by using flanneld deamon, there should not be any manual processes needed. Are you using ansible agent from src/agent/ansible?;;;

 > Are you using ansible agent from src/agent/ansible?
 yes
 > can you share steps that you followed to stand up your cluster? 
 ansible-playbook -e "mode=apply" aws.yml
 Essentially, a default installation. Just the source code from src/agent/ansible.

Other reports of the same bug:
 SimonOberzan Nov 29, in the cello chat channel "kept getting connection timeout errors when trying to connect to zookeepers on other hosts." 
 MohammadObaid Nov 16, in the cello chat channel "kafka is restarting again and again" "kafka is unable to communicate with zookeeper"
 MohammadObaid Nov 18, in the cello chat channel "However everytime when ansible created Ubuntu instance I need to quickly ssh into my instances and need to add rules before ansible go for setting fabric architecture."
 and,Nov 29 
"@tongli Well I always ran same ansible playbook script and face same issue everytime . I have to manually ssh into servers and edit iptables setting. If I dont do that then containers couldnt communicate"
 Possibly related to the new jira issue CE-180 also.
 Another github issue about the topic: [https://github.com/moby/moby/issues/30338]
 –
 [~tongliofcary] if you run iptables -L, is the general forwarding rule set to drop or accept? can you ping between all containers?

Solution:
 as mentioned before, what appears to be a good answer is "iptables -P FORWARD ACCEPT";;;

column1: Cello Ansible - Wait for Instances to Start
column37:
During testing, initial AWS Ansible provisioning occasionally failed due to an error that python was not installed. This was sporadic.

Python is installed by src/agent/ansible/roles/cloud_aws/provision/templates/ubuntu.j2

The delay while waiting for a new server is here: src/agent/ansible/roles/cloud_os/postprovision/tasks/apply.yml

- name: Wait until servers are up and runnning
 wait_for:
 host: "\{\{ item }}"
 port: 22
 state: started
 delay: 15
 connect_timeout: 20
 timeout: 300
 with_items: "\{\{ groups['allnodes'] }}"

Changing this section to have "delay: 60" instead of "delay: 15" solves the problem.
Possible explanation: The current resource is waiting for port 22. However, port 22 does not guarantee python has completed installation yet.
column38: Ubuntu 16.04, Cello Ansible v0.7, Docker 1.13.1, AWS

I think that the best way will be adding a parameter as a wait time in the cloud configuraiton file so that you can adjust that value according to your need. It will be nice to have a patch set on this.;;;

column1: Cello Ansible - Provisioning more than once
column37:
Let's say that you would like to modify the Ansible configuration very slightly, and re-provision. Just to add one new peer container.

Here is an observation about running Cello Ansible a second time.

Notice that each peer docker container has these volume mounts:

"HostConfig": \{
 "Binds": [
 "/var/run:/host/var/run:rw",
 "/opt/gopath/bc1st/fabric/run/keyfiles:/etc/hyperledger/allorgs:rw",
 "/opt/gopath/bc1st/fabric/run/keyfiles/orga/peers/peer1st-orga.orga:/etc/hyperledger/fabric:rw"
 ],

When you run Ansible again, it deletes and recreates those directories. The Bind Volume is lost. The directory /opt/gopath/bc1st/fabric/run/keyfiles is deleted and recreated, however the docker container does not see the new directory. This may be an expected result for Docker.

At least one solution might be to restart the container. Currently Cello Ansible is not doing that.

Next,

There could be additional problems involved with "Provisioning more than once". It would be helpful if the documentation specifically addressed this, having a section about running Ansible multiple times. Is this supported, what issues might occur, if any. Will the blockchain be affected? Could it be done in a live production environment?
column138: 27/Feb/18 1:26 PM;tongliofcary;the behavior run against a cloud is entirely based on the cloud modules. for example, if you try to create a vm on openstack cloud, if the vm with the same name already exist, then it will use that vm. but in aws, it works very differently, it does not matter if a vm with that name already exists, it will always create another one. so the behavir can not be really controlled by ansible agent. also, each run create brand new set of certificates. What can be improved is that we can check the particular certificates directory and see if we need to recreate, but that can be a problem when peers and orderers added. It will be quite a big deal and I do not think cryptogen currently supports it.;;;

column1: Cello Ansible - AWS Security Group enhancement
column37:
The AWS Security Group created by Cello Ansible is defined in /src/agent/ansible/roles/cloud_aws/prepare/tasks/apply.yml

1. If the rules for the ec2_group loaded in Ansible variables, "default variables", rather than hardcoded values, then it would be easier for customers to leverage these Ansible scripts, by overriding the the Security Group rules as necessary for their environment. The existing settings which allows 0.0.0.0, all traffic, is very open and should be customizable.  

2. The ansible ec2_group resource has the feature: "Rules list may include its own name in `group_name`. This allows idempotent loopback additions (e.g. allow group to access itself)." Perhaps _some_ of the rules could have such a setting. I.e., only allow the Fabric group to have access, rather than the world (0.0.0.0).

column139: 25/May/18 10:48 PM;tongliofcary;this is still open. Would very much like some contributions. The issue is that to make fabric network work in a cloud, security rules have been created. currently it uses 0.0.0.0, it is certainly possible to make it configurable. Contributions are welcome.;;;

column1: Port mapping solution need to be updated
column37: For every “fabric-1.0” cluster, we assign a set of worker ports for them, however, we are not actually mapping the container port to worker port, furthermore, we don’t expose the hole cluster to external, only one peer and one ca was exposed. As far as I concerned, we should refine the mapping solution, make every component of “fabric-1.0” cluster can be accessed from external.

column1: make docker fails on s390x
column37:
make docker fails for s390x (+*s390x/debian:jessie*+) while building mongo-docker. Here's the reason why :-

*mongodb-enterprise-mongos : Depends: libc6 (>= 2.23) but 2.19-18+deb8u10 is to be installed*
 *mongodb-enterprise-server : Depends: libc6 (>= 2.23) but 2.19-18+deb8u10 is to be installed*
             *Depends: libpci3 (>= 1:3.3.1-1) but 1:3.2.1-3 is to be installed*
             *Depends: libsnmp30 (>= 5.7.3+dfsg-1ubuntu4~dfsg) but 5.7.2.1+dfsg-1 is to be installed*
 *mongodb-enterprise-shell : Depends: libc6 (>= 2.23) but 2.19-18+deb8u10 is to be installed*
 *mongodb-enterprise-tools : Depends: libc6 (>= 2.23) but 2.19-18+deb8u10 is to be installed*
 *E: Unable to correct problems, you have held broken packages.*

The *libc6*/*libpci3**/**libsnmp30* libraries should be provided by community to progress.
column139: 30/Nov/17 11:32 PM;baohua;Seems u just comment out the DOCKER_BASE_s390x=s390x/debian:jessie? U mean we wanna temporarily disable it, right? ;;;
column140: 30/Nov/17 11:40 PM;harsha544;That's right. Temporarily disable else this would break on s390x.;;;

column1: Refactor docker-compose and Dockerfile & make it arch independent
column37: In continuation to https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/CE-170 . There should be generic Dockerfile and docker-compose*yml files that should leverage CE-170 changes. Doing so one should be able to seamlessly bring up cello on any arch.

Create space/repos in hyperledger dockerhub account for cello
column37:
Cello now creates 3 new images : cello-baseimage, cello-mongo, cello-nginx.
We need to create space (or repos) in hyperledger dockerhub account to stage these.

These images would have a *:$ARCH-$VERSION* docker tag associated with them, which acts as a unique tag between archs.

column144:
06/Dec/17 2:11 PM;baohua;[https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/15963/]

2 questions:

1) How can CI push to dockerhub without username/password?

2) And how can CI decide when (should be only for release or merged) to push?;;;
column145:
12/Dec/17 11:01 AM;harsha544;Hi Baohua,

To answer your questions :- 

1) How can CI push to dockerhub without username/password ?

Just like this is done for fabric-docker image release via [https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/view/fabric-app/job/fabric-app-image-release-docker-ppc64le/configure-readonly/]  pass relevant values to variable from here [https://github.com/hyperledger/cello/blob/master/Makefile#L108] which would assure arch. specific docker images are published.

2) And how can CI decide when (should be only for release or merged) to push?

We should probably update *IS_RELEASE* tag as *true* whenever we plan for a release which is set here [https://github.com/hyperledger/cello/blob/master/Makefile#L20]

To summarize we should be creating a cello-release-*$ARCH* jobs under [https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/view/cello/] which should be executing following commands :-

make docker 
 make install;;;

column1: build target change caused containers not being found
column37: fabric build target docker has been reduced not to build zookeeper, kafka and couchdb images. this change breaks the ansible agent when docker is a build target but the images are missing. We need to change this to allow compose and k8s draw specific zookeeper, kafka, fabric-ca and couchdb images from docker hub.

column1: Provide full Dockerfile to trigger dockerhub's auto building
column37:
Dockerhub need a full version of Dockerfile inside the project to trigger the auto-building.

We need add some under each image.
column138:
13/Dec/17 2:54 PM;harsha544;Hi [~baohua],

Given the recent changes to the following docker hub repo's i.e linking with Github's auto-trigger feature :- 
[https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/cello-mongo/]
[https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/cello-nginx/]
[https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/cello-baseimage/]

I am not sure if [Dockerfile.in|https://github.com/hyperledger/cello/blob/master/config/baseimage/Dockerfile.in#L1] can be consumed as-is since make will be performing a variable substitution to *_DOCKER_BASE___* in the above Dockerfile.in and would generate a arch specific Dockerfile and later that would be consumed as-is . I am not sure if github's auto trigger functionality might support this.

Alternatively we can switch to CI for x86/ppc64le/s390x. Please share your thoughts.;;;
column139:
13/Dec/17 6:04 PM;baohua;[~harsha544]

after evaluation, nfortunately, dockerhub only support a full-version of docker file.

Hence for the x86 base images, let's provide a full version of dockerfile.

I'm fine if the ci can support the template file for ppc and s390 ones.;;;
column140:
13/Dec/17 6:37 PM;harsha544;[~baohua] Sure I will leverage this JIRA Item. to put a patch for x86. 
Thank you. !!;;;
column141: 18/Dec/17 1:22 PM;harsha544;Here's the PR - [https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/16275] .We can test now.;;;
column142: 18/Dec/17 1:30 PM;baohua;Docker hub can only access name Dockefile now, hence we can put them under different dirs.;;;
column143: 18/Dec/17 1:32 PM;harsha544;Re-structuring the code to align with the Dockerhub's specs.;;;
column144: 18/Dec/17 1:53 PM;harsha544;[~baohua] I have updated the Code [https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/16275] ;;;
column145: 19/Dec/17 10:28 AM;baohua;[~harsha544], Seems for other images, we need to use `FROM hyperledger/cello-baseimage:x86_64-latest`;;;
column146:
19/Dec/17 12:03 PM;harsha544;[~baohua] I assumed the docker tagging convention per this [https://github.com/hyperledger/cello/blob/master/Makefile#L26] should result into :-

hyperledger/cello-baseimage:x86_64-0.8.0 
&
 hyperledger/cello-baseimage:latest

Hence the tag should be `FROM hyperledger/cello-baseimage` .

If we follow `FROM hyperledger/cello-baseimage:x86_64-latest` convention I foresee many issues cropping up since the docker-compose.yaml files have all `FROM hyperledger/cello-baseimage` since this is architecturally independent.;;;
column147:
19/Dec/17 1:05 PM;baohua;[~harsha544], oh, not to these files.

 I mean the Dockefile to build other images in dockerhub, like `[https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/16275/5/dockerhub/mongo/Dockerfile]`. This is because dockerhub will use the base image in its repo to build out, however, there is only `hyperledger/cello-baseimage:x86_64-latest` one.;;;
column148: 19/Dec/17 1:12 PM;harsha544;Alright, I will push the mentioned changes.;;;

column1: Enable s390x back in cello
Add Dockerfile for v0.8.0 & v0.8.0-alpha
column37:
Now we have Dockerfiles under `dockerhub/` for the latest tag.

And we need to figure out how to trigger dockerhub build images with specific tag.

e.g.,

baseimage:x86_64-0.8.0

 

Note currently dockerhub can use code with given branch or git tag.

 

One workaround is to add an additional subdir for each release, and use the release tag as image tags.

column1: Create New Cello-Jenkins Job
column37:
[~rameshthoomu] Request you to create new jenkins jobs for ppc64le & s390x under [https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/view/cello/] . With naming convention as `cello-release-$ARCH`

In build section of those jobs only these commands will be executed, we can leverage existing nodes/servers utilized for fabric for publishing the images.

make docker
 make install

Which should publish images to :-

[https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/cello-baseimage/]
 [https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/cello-mongo/]
[https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/cello-nginx/]

FWIW, we would need same credentials similar to [https://hub.docker.com/u/hyperledger/] inorder to publish the docker images

^^^ [~baohua]
column139: 20/Dec/17 1:30 AM;rameshthoomu;When you need this to trigger? On the release tag ?;;;

column142:
20/Dec/17 10:34 PM;baohua;Do we have all the base images in dockerhub now?

If so, we can config building images for all platforms in dockerhub.

Potential steps:
 # run `TAG=0.8.0 make gen_dockerfile` to create the full dockerfiles inside v0.8.0 dir for all archs.
 # Config dockerhub to use the given dockerfile to generate the images with given release tag and archs.;;;
column143:
20/Dec/17 11:33 PM;harsha544;Except for x86_64 baseimage there no other arch's baseimage  available in dockerhub. The jenkins job can be triggered when *RELEASE=true* is set and in next subsequent PR *RELEASE=false*.

[~baohua] there isn't a make target `gen_dockerfile` as far as my understanding is. Also TAG value will be overridden with default inside Makefile.

However updating Makefile with *RELEASE=true* and *BASE_VERSION=0.8.0* followed by make docker should generate the required docker images & the Dockerfiles with version 0.8.0. Also the Dockerfiles under `build/` directory. 

 Will try updating/creating a new target gen_dockerfile inside Makefile and work as part of CE-202.;;;
column144:
20/Dec/17 11:40 PM;baohua;Yes, there is no such cmd now, and i just suggested that we add it.

As u may know, the dockerhub can only parse full dockerfile without any variables.

Hence we need the full dockerfiles (for each version, and each arch) inside the project if wanna trigger the image building at dockerhub automatically.

Make sense?;;;

*dashboard         | [2018-01-11 16:40:10,207] DEBUG [agent.docker.docker_swarm] [docker_swarm.py:428           compose_up()] - template path ./agent/docker/_compose_files/fabric-1.0/local*

column1: Support Hyperledger Compose in the started network
column37:
Similar as the blockchain-explorer, Hyperledger Compose is another useful tool.

We can let cello start the network with enabling Hyperledger Compose service.
column138:
28/Feb/18 2:13 PM;LordGoodman;Hi baohua, I'm almost finished the deployment of this feature,  this comment is meant to briefly describe my work.

There are three kinds of images under the hyperledger/composer dockerhub repo, names and functions are listed below:
 # Composer-playground: Dashboard of Composer.
 # Composer-cli: Command line client of Composer.
 # Composer-rest-api:  RESTful API of Composer.

I only integrated the playground into cello, and Composer has an important concept named "card" which is used to import existing Fabric network, user can create and import cards manually through the playground, however, I prefer pre-create cards and import it into playground container, so that user can operate Fabric network directly once playground is running rather than create card files at first, but the generation of card files need the certificate of org's admin user, which means we need to regenerate the cards once crypto-config dir is updated.

I also have a concern,  Composer-playground need logs of memory and CPU resources to run, multiple playground containers running on the same docker host might cost a large performance degradation, maybe we should disable playground by default, and provide an option to set up playground while user creating chain.;;;
column139:
28/Feb/18 4:07 PM;baohua;[~LordGoodman], thanks so much for your design.

I agree with your concern.

And would suggest:

1) We can use existing/pre-created credentials since the crypto-config is static now. We may change it to dynamic way later.

2) Yes, it costs resources, we may introduce some new network type/option in the dashboard to indicate whether wanna a composer. But i'm fine if you wanna make it by default and have a quick implementation. We can do the optimization later.

Thanks!;;;

column1: Setup Fabric with CouchDB
column37:
Per this [https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/cello?msg=2KvefeBauToMrW69N] Creating the JIRA item.

More description on this issue. 

Creating a chain from operator dashboard reads these configuration files ([https://github.com/hyperledger/cello/tree/master/src/agent/docker/_compose_files/fabric-1.0]). But any change in these files will not be detected by the dashboard while creating the chain. 

Example, the current version of these configuration files use goleveldb as a state database. To use CouchDB, updating the docker compose file should work. But the dashboard is not creating the container to serve CouchDB. The dashboard always create the following (4 peers, 2 ca, orderer/ kafkas, explorer and cli )
column138:
10/Mar/18 7:29 PM;harsha544;The existing files under [https://github.com/hyperledger/cello/tree/master/src/agent/docker/_compose_files/fabric-1.0] which are leveraged are fabric-solo & fabric-kafka, this JIRA's intent is to provide equivalent fabric-solo-couchdb & fabric-kafka-couchdb files as add-on.

[~Amir-Teshome] this feature will be added in v0.9.0 release of cello. Any further follow-ups should be done via comment section.;;;

column1: Cello Ansible - Remove some hardcoded defaults
column37:
_ansible-playbook -e "mode=apply" aws.yml_ seems to fail when using any region other than us-east1, does not allow you to specify a non-default VPC, and always uses the first subnet.
 # By default, this picks the default VPC. The VPC ID should be configurable.
 # By default, this picks the first subnet in the region. The Subnet ID should be configurable.
 # By default, the AMI ID is hardcoded with a _us-east1_ ID. _ec2_ami_find_ is already being called, and will return the region-specific AMI ID for us. FYI this ID is being set as a fact (_ubuntu_ami_id)_ but appears to be unused.
column138:
09/Feb/18 5:09 AM;bleggett;Submitted PR.

 
 * VPC can now be specified, if you have more than one.
 * Subnet can now be specified, if you have more than one.
 * Removed AMI ID, as that can be derived at runtime in a region-agnostic way.;;;

column1: Support pulling newer images
Tweak Ansible worker readme and simplify apt installation process
column37:
-Out of the box with AWS, the ansible agent defaults to using the latest Ubuntu 16.04 AMI.-

-This AMI no longer ships with python2, by default it ships with python3.-

-However, the ansible playbook assumes (but does not ensure) a python2 environment (it installs pip2 and not pip3 on nodes, etc) and will fail.-

 -- 

-Since it's relatively simple to modify the node creation scripts to work under a python3 environment, and that seems cleaner than explicitly installing a python2 environment on each node, going to go ahead and submit a PR that does that.-

 

The above was the result of poor understanding on my part, so I am updating this to include the small tweaks I made while figuring out that I was wrong :D

column1: Refactor of Kubernetes agent
column37:
There are some relative jobs have been done for Kubernetes agent development, however, they are manifests which are not packaged into Cello's agent class, for that reason, users might not use Kubernetes as the underline management platform for Fabric cluster through Cello runtime.

This item is meant to refactor the previous work and integrate functions of Kubernetes client into Cello.

column1: Develop host class for Kubernetes agent according to base agent class
column37: Kubernetes agent host for Cello is used to communicate with existing Kubernetes cluster, checking the availability and health of the cluster.

column1: Develop cluster class for Kubernetes agent according to base agent class
column37: Kubernetes agent cluster of Cello is used to manger deployments among Kubernetes clusters just like cluster class in Docker agent.

column1: Development of necessary files to deploy Fabric on Kubernetes
column37: Some setup files are needed for this task, there are Fabric setup files, Kubernetes deployment files as well as Explorer config file and Composer card files.
column138:
21/Mar/18 2:31 PM;yopep;Hi [~LordGoodman] and [~allenyang],

I'd like to know the design on how do you go about implementing the code to deploy Fabric to a Kubernetes cluster. As I understand it there are three solutions existing in the Cello source codes.

 

Solution 1:
 * Use src/agent/k8s where deployment is via shell scripts

Solution 2:
 * Use src/agent/ansible where Ansible is used

Solution 3:
 * Use src/agent/k8s-operator where Kubernetes Operator will be used (No codes yet)

 

I'm asking because I would like to help in implementing it and so that our efforts can be harmonized.;;;
column139: 13/Apr/18 7:11 PM;LordGoodman;[~yopep] Please refer to this link:[https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Z52BC95Jfx8i_i9XB18PBVnHt17YU3PeyIq0nWclF8g/edit?usp=sharing];;;

Master Address : 'k8s_master_address'

Credential type: 'k8s_cred_type'

Certificate content: 'k8s_cert'

Key content: 'k8s_key'

Configuration content: 'k8s_config'

Username: 'k8s_username'

column1: k8s now requires fail-swap-on to be set to false
column37:
k8s fails kubelet if your system swap flag is on. Kubelet won't fail in the past but now if the swap is on from your operating system, kubelet will fail to start. The solution is to set that kubelet flag fail-swap-on to false. Then kubelet will work appropriately. but the real solution is to set the system swap off like using this command 

sudo swapoff -a

need more image tags
column37:
ansible agent uses two images tags to setup fabric network.
one tag for fabric images such as peer, orderer, ccenv, tools and ca
one tag for kafka, zookeeper, couchdb etc.

The issue is that in test env, when cello sets up fabric network, testers may want to use snapshot images for fabric peer, orderer, ccenv, tools, these snapshot images won't be available from ca since ca images get built in its own repo and there won't be match ca snapshot images. We need to introduce a ca tag.

column1: support kafka consensus mode.
Resolve remaining license scan issues found by Fossology
column37:
h1. Context

Hyperledger Cello source files (from April 3, 2018) were scanned by The Linux Foundation utilizing Fossology to determine license for files contained in the following repositories:
 *   https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/cello
 *   https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/cello-analytics
 *   https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/cello-k8s-operator

From the Hyperledger Charter (https://www.hyperledger.org/about/charter) Section 13, all files that are included in Hyperledger projects should either be licensed with the Apache License, Version 2.0 for source code or Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License for documentation.
h1. Expected Behavior

All files should have license text included either directly or via a LICENSE file in the directory for files that cannot be modified to include a comment with the license text (think binary files).
h1. Actual Behavior

See attached results of scan.
h1. To Fix

The package metadata files (generally bower.json / package.json for NPM) incorrectly describe the Hyperledger Cello as licensed under ISC, rather than Apache. NPM's default is ISC so this is a common mistake. I've highlighted these instances in the attached reports. These files should be changed from ISC to Apache-2.0.

For files with Attribution license, ideally, we would replace those with Apache 2.0 files and dependencies; otherwise, we will need to go to the Hyperledger Governing board for exception.

For _ALL_ files that do not have a license included, the first step is to check with the contributor to ensure that the file can be released as Apache 2.0 or CC-BY-4.0. If the contributor agrees, the file should be modified to include the license. You can utilize [SPDX Identifiers](https://spdx.org/) to represent the correct license.

For those non-modifiable files, you will need to include a LICENSE file in the directory containing the license that the files are covered by. Here are a few examples of how this might be done:
* [OPNFV Apex](https://github.com/opnfv/apex/blob/master/LICENSE.rst) -- this is an example of explicitly calling out Apache 2.0 for source code and CC-BY-4.0 for docs. 
* [containerd](https://github.com/containerd/containerd/blob/master/README.md) -- see notice at bottom. This also calls out the separate Apache / CC-BY-4.0 docs, and explicitly references the "docs" directory.
h1. *Before closing this bug, please let me know that you have made the above changes. I will then run the code through Fossology again* *to ensure the changes.*

21/Jun/18 3:23 PM;baohua;[~tkuhrt]

Is there a new version of scan result?

Thanks!;;;

column1: Ansible Agent - aws.yml stops with cryptogen file not found
column37:
*Symptom:* 

Ansible aws.yml playbook stops with error when trying to generate crypto certs with cryptogen. Apparently the binary is not available on the host (see attachment)

*Steps:*
 * Fresh AWS account (using ap-southeast-2 region)
 * setup a ubuntu bastion host to run the ansible playbooks from
 * following this guide: [https://github.com/hyperledger/cello/blob/master/docs/worker_ansible_howto.md]
 * created ssh keys and started ssh-agent as per guide
 * edited cello/src/agent/ansible/vars/aws.yml as per guide (only changed access keys and region, nothing else)
 * started playbook with ansible-playbook -e "mode=apply" aws.yml
 * the playbook stops with error (see screenshot)
column38: AWS, ubuntu 16.04 ansible host, git clone master
column138:
30/Apr/18 12:01 PM;harsha544;Can you try staging the binaries in mentioned path and retry the operation as such ?

And I presume you have done this already [https://github.com/hyperledger/cello/blob/master/docs/worker_ansible_howto.md#setup-fabric-network] ?;;;
column139:
30/Apr/18 12:08 PM;careck;Hi Krishna,
 # not sure how to "stage the binaries" I know where they should be (because they aren't there) but I'm not sure where to get them from.
 # I'm using the "convenience" playbook described on the same page but further down: [https://github.com/hyperledger/cello/blob/master/docs/worker_ansible_howto.md#convenient-configurations-and-commands]

I saw this playbook executed successfully in a youtube video (by hightall) and did exactly what he did in the video. ;;;
column141:
30/Apr/18 1:15 PM;harsha544;By "Staging" I mean downloading binaries from nexus repository. You can download and stage the binaries by following the steps mentioned here :-

[http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.1/samples.html?highlight=binaries#download-platform-specific-binaries] 

To summarize you would be doing this :- 

curl -sSL https://goo.gl/6wtTN5 | bash -s *1.1.**0*  , 

Ensure you pass Hyperledger Fabric's tags as such.;;;
column142:
30/Apr/18 4:27 PM;careck;OK, thanks for the hint, that worked. So here is what I did:
 # started with a clean slate
 # instead of using the aws.yml playbook, I used the individual ones:
 # ansible-playbook -e "mode=apply env=aws cloud_type=aws" provcluster.yml
 # ansible-playbook -i run/runhosts -e "mode=apply env=aws env_type=flanneld" initcluster.yml
 # ansible-playbook -i run/runhosts -e "mode=apply env=bc1st deploy_type=compose" setupfabric.yml
 # --> this stopped with the error cryptogen not found
 # ssh into the machine and curl -sSL [https://goo.gl/6wtTN5] | bash -s *1.1.**0* 
 # **copying the binaries from fabric-sample/bin to /opt/gopath/bc1st/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/build/
 # replay the fabric setup: ansible-playbook -i run/runhosts -e "mode=apply env=bc1st deploy_type=compose" setupfabric.yml

This worked!

So that means that the step in the setupfabric playbook that downloads the cryptogen binary is not working! Looking throught the ansible files, I believe that the problem is in this file:

*/cello/src/agent/ansible/roles/deploy_compose/fabricbuild/tasks/build.yml*

Unfortunately I'm not an ansible expert so I can't debug this.;;;
column143: 25/May/18 9:55 PM;tongliofcary;for this issue, the problem is that the configuration in vars/bc1st.yml does not have the right url for ansible agent to pull cryptogen binary. Once that is configured right, it will work. I am closing this.;;;
column144:

bin: "https://nexus.hyperledger.org/content/repositories/releases/org/hyperledger/fabric/hyperledger-fabric/linux-amd64-1.1.0/hyperledger-fabric-linux-amd64-1.1.0.tar.gz";;;

column1: Make ansible agent be able to deploy onto existing k8s
column37: Make ansible agent be able to deploy onto exisitng k8s. Ansible agent currently can only deploy fabric onto k8s environment it sets up. This patch will allow a user to use any existing k8s environment to stand up a fabric network

column1: error in executing ansible playbook

TASK [Download fabric binaries] ************************************************fatal: [cloud]: FAILED! => \{"failed": true, "msg": "ERROR! file or module does not exist: /home/ibmadmin/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric-test/cello/src/agent/ansible/roles/deploy_k8s/https:/nexus.hyperledger.org/content/repositories/releases/org/hyperledger/fabric/hyperledger-fabric/linux-amd64-1.1.0/hyperledger-fabric-linux-amd64-1.1.0.tar.gz"}

column1: Make k8s playbooks compatible with Mac OS
column37:
There are few steps fails on Mac OS. The following needs to be taken care to make playbooks work with Mac OS.


1. Change the `vb1st.yaml` file to point to the darwin binaries
*ex: *
{code}bin: "https://nexus.hyperledger.org/content/repositories/releases/org/hyperledger/fabric/hyperledger-fabric/$(uname -s|tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]'|sed 's/mingw64_nt.*/windows/')-amd64-1.1.0/hyperledger-fabric-$(uname -s|tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]'|sed 's/mingw64_nt.*/windows/')-amd64-1.1.0.tar.gz"{code}

2. By default script downloads linux based kubectl, it should point to darwin for mac os
  change to be taken care in file ----> _cello/src/agent/ansible/roles/deploy_k8s/getbin/tasks/apply.yml_
*ex:*
 {code}

url: "https://storage.googleapis.com/kubernetes-release/release/v1.10.3/bin/$(uname -s|tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]'|sed 's/mingw64_nt.*/windows/')/amd64/kubectl"{code}

Make sure you delete the above binaries, when you run next time

3. pvc creation attempts need to be increased from 5 to some optimal value
   
4. make sure the script takes care of creating the folder *run* (For storing logs etc.,)

column1: Add ansible plays to update BNA on existing network
column37: There are currently no ansible plays that take advantage of the "composer network update" command. The only way to perform a chaincode update via command line, currently, is to ssh into the master node and run it from there. Simplifying it to a single ansible play would be helpful.

A docker host is expected to have a single VM and hence a single node.

column1: Change deployment to support equal distribution of pods across nodes in Cello/ansible

column1: Allow resource allocation for k8s install
column37: Ansible agent now can be used to install fabric network onto an existing k8s env. But fabric pods are not providing required and memory and cpu requirement, this makes k8s pods scheduler won't be able to place pods correctly or limit the number of pods running on a k8s cluster node, we need to add the resource tags for the pods deployment.

column138:
09/Jul/18 11:03 AM;qsmen;To be safe and for production scenario,  here is some suggestions for Cello.

1. Suppose two orgs want to construct a fabric network, and the requirements are: org1 requires 2 peers, org2 requires 1 peer, each maintains their own fabric CA, and uses the kafka consensus. 2. The blockchain service provider(BSP) provides nodes and necessary software are installed.

3.each org's admin  start the fabric CA-servers of the two orgs. When CA1 server and CA2 server are started for the first time, they each will generate self-signed certificates as org’s certificates.

4.Start the user dashboard on org1-peer0 and org2-peer0. The admins of the two orgs login their respective user dashboards and register and enroll their Admin certificates with their respective CAs. Similarly peers, client app user and orders get their own certificate from their org’s CA, respectively.

5  one org's admin configure the order profile and channel profile,  Start up the order system on behalft of other org's  admin by obtaining their signatures.

6.The admin of org1 logs in to the user dashboard, creates channel and have peers join channel.

7.The admins of org1 and org2 log in to the user dashboard, install chaincode and instantiate chaincode. Client app invoke chaincode and so on.;;;

column1: ansible agent fails when only deploy peers or orderers
column37: Ansible agent was developed to deploy both peers and orderers, but in some cases, it may get used to only deploy peers or orderers, in these cases, the ansible agent fails. We need to fix this issue so that the agent can be used to deploy either peer or orderer or both.

column1: A suggestion of the cello project
column37:
I think that the current management mode of cello as a baas does not conform to the principle of the fabric-chain :
Current workflow:
   1.The administrator creates a chain: test-chain, initializes all nodes;
   2.Users use this chain: alppy test-chain;
   3.User Install and manage smart contracts: install and manage chaincodes;

One chain is managed by the user, This mode is like managing  cloud service.This approach violates the principle of blockchains, which does not take advantage of multiple channels. Take  the bitcoin as an example. One user manages a mining pool or a mining machine, not a chain.
Why don't we do like this:

   1.Users must first register an organization;
   2. Administrator creates peer cluster and CA center for users;
   3. The originator of the alliance creates an orderer cluster to invite others to join an channel.
   4. Other users choose the channel to join, and add their peer cluster and ca node into the channel.
   Each user is not oriented to a chain, but to their own cluster, in order to meet the characteristics of one union blockchain.

Baohua Yang
Jul 3   #129  

Zhipeng

Thanks a lot for your thoughts!

Yes, i agree with you that we may move to that direction.

As you may find in the project proposal, the very initial goal of Cello is to help setup a baas, where all resources are managed by a single vendor.

Recently, people have proposed similar thoughts to expand Cello to a more flexible model, like what you said, each org owns its nodes, and they join together as a consortium. And requirements are reported with that flexible model, too. The team have considered it for quite a while, and now we think it as a long term target, and have started by refining the existing credential generation and providing a user management mechanism.

We would very much welcome you help add ur thoughts into that proposal, and let's well define a new operation model, in order to help people utilize Hyperledger technologies better.

Thanks again!

This is one topic: https://lists.hyperledger.org/g/cello/topic/23022876#128

column1: adding V1_3 capabilities to ansible agent

column1: No /usr/app/src path in the user-dashboard image
column37:
In the user-dashboard, there is no /usr/app/src path.

But in the docker-compose.yaml, the default container running cmd is command: bash -c "cd /usr/app/src && [ "$DEV" = True ] && npm run dev || npm start"”

30/Jul/18 9:33 AM;Samurai123;Steps i took to setup: 

 

1) sudo apt install git

2) sudo apt install make

3) $ git clone http://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/cello && cd cello

4) $ make setup-master

5) $ sudo make start

6) $ sudo systemctl stop docker.service

7) $ sudo dockerd -H tcp://0.0.0.0:2375 -H unix:///var/run/docker.sock --api-cors-header='*' --default-ulimit=nofile=8192:16384 --default-ulimit=nproc=8192:16384 -D &

8) $ docker -H Worker_Node_IP:2375 info

9) $ ssh L31208@IPAddress

10) $ MASTER_NODE_IP=172.20.129.158 make setup-worker

11)$ cd cello

12) $ sudo make start

column1: Update certificates and deployment template for Kubernetes agent
column37:
The pre-exist credentials on user dashboard is matched with Fabric cluster created by docker agent, however it is different from Fabric cluster created by Kubernetes agent, thus Chains on Kubernetes type host could not be applied through user dashboard, this item is meant to update the credentials of the Kubernetes agent.

NOTE: please expect this will be a huge patch !

column1: Create a "mychannel" for user dashboard
column37: Due to the network policy of the Kubernetes, "mychannel" can not be created in user dashboard, we need to create "mychannel" on back end once the Fabric cluster was created, after then, Fabric cluster hosted by Kubernetes agent could be maintain through user dashboard.

column1: Can not install chaincode in User dashboad
column37: Currently, The user dashboard is enabled TLS when connect to Fabric cluster, however the Fabric cluster hosted by kubernetes agent deny TLS traffic by default, therefore, when the user dashboard try to connect the cluster hosted by kubernetes agent should disable the TLS protocol.

column1: Hard-Coded AWS access key id in aws.yml
column37: in /cello/src/agent/ansible/vars/aws.yml, line 6 contains a hard-coded AWS access key id. This is an issue for portability, as well as a (minor) security flaw. We should change this to read the standard AWS env var 'AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID'

column1: Root Persistence Device Misnamed
column37: In cello/src/agent/ansible/roles/cloud_aws/provision/tasks/apply.yml, the aws device name of the root disk is misnamed. xvda is used for external, non root EBS volume mounts. However, this description is describing a root volume on this instance, which by convention is mounted on /dev/sda1. We should fix that to reflect the proper device name.

column1: Accelerate the process of releasing chain in Kubernetes agent
column37:
Currently, the releasing chain process will take long time since it will clean the resource first, after the agent confirms all resource has been eliminated then redeploy the resource. 
As HaiTao's advice, we can simply delete the peer's pod and relative volume and restart the pod, this should be able to save a lot of time

column1: Genesis block not found with creating fabric cluster of kafka consensus type
column37: When creating Fabric cluster on Kubernetes agent with kafka consensus type, the orderer pod will throw out an error about "genesis.block not found", because the genesis block should call "orderer.genesis.block".

column1: Unable to remove resource on NFS server
column37: Currently, the delete chain operation won't work when user try to delete chain with kafka consensus hosted by the Kubernetes agent, because the agent try to remove the resource folder before the pv has been deleted entirely, this patch add logic to ensure the folder removal will happen after the pv is deleted.

column1: Fix envsubst in macOS
column37:
When run `make restart` at macOS, it will report "/bin/sh: envsubst: command not found".


Solution:
* brew install gettext
* brew link gettext
* echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/gettext/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.bash_profile

column1: Fabric 1.2 restart after applied in user dashboard
column37:
steps:
master node:
1. git clone  https://github.com/hyperledger/cello.git
2. cd cello && make start
docker worker node:
1. git clone  https://github.com/hyperledger/cello.git
2. cd cello && MASTER_NODE=10.112.80.119 make setup-worker
operator dashboard:
1. create fabric 1.2 chain in docker node
user dashboard:
1. apply fabric 1.2 chain
Then peer docker container will be restarted random

column1: Ansible agent should create yaml connection profile
column37: Ansible agent currently only create json connection profile. In some cases such as fabric go-sdk prefers the yaml connection profile. To satisfy that requirement,we should create same connection profile but in yaml format.

column1: Ansible agent should use public IP for endpoint
column37: Ansible agent uses component name to communicate with other components in K8S env. It works well when all components are in the same cluster. It breaks when components are scattered in multiple clusters. We need improvement to allow the connection profile to use the k8s public IP address and service port as part of all endpoints.

column1: Multiple cloud connection file needs entityMatchers
column37: When a fabric network has nodes from multiple cloud, the endpoints must be using public DNS names or IP addresses. A section named entityMatchers is needed in the connection profile for clients to be able to connect to the network. We need to extend the connection profile to include that section.

column1: "apt" usage in a loop via squash_actions is deprecated in ansible version 2.11
column37:
*DEPRECATION WARNING*

2018-11-14 10:36:05,474 p=12601 u=ubuntu | [DEPRECATION WARNING]: Invoking "apt" only once while using a loop via squash_actions is deprec
ated. Instead of using a loop to supply
multiple items and specifying `name: \{{ item }}`, please use `name: [[u'python-pip', u'docker-ce', u'libtool', u'libltdl-dev',
u'autoconf']]` and remove the loop. This feature will be removed in version 2.11. Deprecation warnings can be disabled by setting
deprecation_warnings=False in ansible.cfg.

column141: 03/Dec/18 10:28 PM;hightall;[~eric_mesquita] yes, the variable value notified is wrong, and because the key cloak will initial for open id client creation, if the /opt/cello/keycloak-mysql directory not exists, because you got some thing wrong at the first time, so this directory will be created, and at the second time, will not initial key cloak server, so I think you need remove  /opt/cello/keycloak-mysql and relaunch again.;;;

column1: ansible agent should include other org's peers when generate connection profile
column37: currently ansible agent only include peers from its own org for its connection profile. It does not include other orgs peers, this is a problem for sending transactions. Peers from other orgs need to be added into connection profile.

column1: Replace cryptogen tool with CA in Kubernetes agent
column37:
In the current design, the certificates used by peer/orderer are generated by `cryptogen` tool, it is a restriction that the certificates must be created first and some of them need to be hard coded into deployment files.
To resolve the problem mentioned above, CA must be introduced and be responsible for dispatching certs/credential to peer/orderer during the network creation.

column1: Unable to Login Cello Dashboard After Installation
column37:

[http://xx.xx.xx.xx:8083/auth/realms/cello-realm/protocol/openid-connect/auth?client_id=cello-operator-dashboard&redirect_uri=http%3A%2F%2Fxx.xx.xx.xx:%3A8080%2Foidc_callback&scope=openid+email&access_type=offline&response_type=code&state=eyJjc3JmX3Rva2VuIjogInAxenFid1VMQnI0U2N4T05QYVNqc1luejhmMHMxN3diIiwgImRlc3RpbmF0aW9uIjogImV5SmhiR2NpT2lKSVV6STFOaUo5LkltaDBkSEE2THk4MUxqa3VNamt1TdfdNd09qZ3dPREF2SWcuTnItSmhpN3lXR1puTE1VdEx0Qmc1TUpRZ1N0SlFMeFF3YklLRHI3UDd2VSJ9&openid.realm=http%3A%2F%2Fxx.xx.xx.xx:%3A8080%2Foidc_callback]

column1: Update Cello Docs
column37: Cello Docs ([https://cello.readthedocs.io|https://cello.readthedocs.io/]) have been the same for the past year and a half despite a lot of changes to the project. Instructions are disorganized (mismatches with the github repo readme's), redundant and have outdated requirements list (e.g still refers to any version of Docker 17+ as experimental). Docs related to the Ansible agent does not explain how to deploy custom chaincode, using different versions of Fabric etc.

column38:
h2. Environment

Ubuntu 16.04 , 

Machine specs: 8 Cores, 16GB RAM
h2. Setup

I used the following procedure (as per the docs) to setup and run the cello master 
 # {{git clone https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/cello && cd cello}}
 # {{cd cello && git checkout v0.9.0}}
 # {{make setup-master}}
 # SERVER_IP_ADDRESS=<server IP> MODE=dev make start
 # make build-user-dashbaord-js

At this point both the dashboards are started up.

column1: "Create chain" operation fails on user dashboard
column37:
h2. Setup

I used the following procedure (as per the docs) to setup and run the cello master 
 # {{git clone [https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/cello] && cd cello}}
 # {{cd cello && git checkout v0.9.0}}
 # {{make setup-master}}
 # SERVER_IP_ADDRESS=<server IP> MODE=dev make start
 # make build-user-dashbaord-js

At this point both the dashboards are started up. 

After both the dashboards start up, a worker is added on operator dashboard
h2. Issue

I'm logged in as admin on the user dashboard. 

I then proceed to create a chain (see below screenshot)

 

!image-2019-01-25-15-33-07-828.png|width=537,height=297!

 

This step gives the following error notification

!image-2019-01-25-15-35-54-786.png!

*The request payload that ges to the API is* 

{"name":"newchain1","type":"fabric-1.0","size":4}

*This results in a 400 (bad request)*

*response body :* \{"success":false}

 
h2. Logs (can be seen when I do "make logs")

!image-2019-01-25-15-59-24-615.png!

column1: User management
column37: I'm using the stable version 0.9 of Cello. When I create users, they all seem to have the same access privileges on the operator dashboard, regardless of role. A plain user can even delete an admin, and edit his own role to become an admin, and manage chains and hosts. A user can delete his own account, and doesn't get logged out from the dashboard

column1: Remove file permission change for a specific user (id:1000 and group:1000)
column37:
The following two playbooks change file permissions for a specific user (id:1000 and group:1000)
 * src/operator-dashboard/agent/ansible/roles/deploy_compose/certsetup/tasks/apply.yml
 * src/operator-dashboard/agent/ansible/roles/deploy_compose/composersetup/tasks/apply.yml

Why do we need this? The user who has ID:1000 is created maybe in the operating system installation. Cello user may not have the privilege to use the account. Can we simply delete the tasks like this?
{noformat}
diff --git a/src/operator-dashboard/agent/ansible/roles/deploy_compose/certsetup/tasks/apply.yml b/src/operator-dashboard/agent/ansible/roles/deploy_compose/certsetup/tasks/apply.yml
index 61c7676..599828e 100755
--- a/src/operator-dashboard/agent/ansible/roles/deploy_compose/certsetup/tasks/apply.yml
+++ b/src/operator-dashboard/agent/ansible/roles/deploy_compose/certsetup/tasks/apply.yml
@@ -96,13 +96,6 @@
     chdir: "{{ fabricworkdir }}"
   when: allorderers | length > 0

-- name: Change file permissions
-  file:
-    path: "{{ fabricworkdir }}"
-    owner: 1000
-    group: 1000
-    recurse: yes
-
 - name: Create ca config file
   template:
     src: "{{ playbook_dir }}/../deploy_compose/certsetup/templates/fabric-ca-server-config.j2"
{noformat}
column95: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Avoid using root in controller machine
column37:
Some playbooks requires the root privilege in a controller machine that a user runs the ansible-playbook command. For example, the first two plays in

src/operator-dashboard/agent/ansible/roles/deploy_compose/plays.yml

configure them to run in local (controller) and requires "become_user: root". But, Cello users may not have the root privilege. Even if they have the privilege, they may not prepare an ssh key to login as root from their normal user context.

Why don't we run the plays with a normal user just by removing the become statements?

Note: In the older Cello implementations, the download and certificate generation run in a remote builder machine. So, I think this was not a problem.
{noformat}
diff --git a/src/operator-dashboard/agent/ansible/roles/deploy_compose/plays.yml b/src/operator-dashboard/agent/ansible/roles/deploy_compose/plays.yml
index 45e1380..9666ca2 100755
--- a/src/operator-dashboard/agent/ansible/roles/deploy_compose/plays.yml
+++ b/src/operator-dashboard/agent/ansible/roles/deploy_compose/plays.yml
@@ -2,8 +2,6 @@
 - name: get fabric crypto tool
   hosts: cloud
   connection: local
-  become: true
-  become_user: root
   vars_files:
     - "./../../vars/{{ env }}.yml"
   tasks:
@@ -13,8 +11,6 @@
 - name: generate certificates
   hosts: cloud
   connection: local
-  become: true
-  become_user: root
   vars_files:
     - "./../../vars/{{ env }}.yml"
   tasks:
{noformat}
column95: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column138: 14/Feb/19 8:49 PM;tongliofcary;[~tkueda]this is indeed an issue. In the past I have tried to remove the use of root account, but there were issues when deal with remote servers with limited permission for example when installing package onto the remote server, when deploy things, we often need to add missing components. But with the direction of moving to k8s as a deployment platform, that problem is no longer an issue, I think we can start removing the root use. A patch set will be a lot help to address this.;;;
column139:
05/Apr/19 9:35 PM;tongliofcary;since ansible agent has been designed to also deal with cloud like provisioning new VMs, stand up k8s, deal with overlay networks, we really need to still use root user for accomplishing these tasks. At present, we can not really remove its use yet.
;;;
column140:
05/Apr/19 9:54 PM;baohua;[~tkueda], based on tong's comment, do you think the issue can be closed?

Thanks!;;;

Thanks,

Arindam;;;

column146:
19/Mar/19 10:38 AM;baohua;v0.9.0 is the latest stable version.

From the logs, seems the master node cannot create chain at the worker node.

I doubt the reason might be the master cannot call the docker API in the worker node, can you verify that?

Besides, you may collect the master node's logs at the moment of creating a chain, there can be some errors if not started successfully.;;;

29/Mar/19 11:06 AM;brendatian;My architecture is x86_64 ubuntu 14.04， the os of my vm is very old and my network is not fluent, so I changed the docker file of the userdashboard.  My steps are not suitable for you I think. FYI, I encountered the same problem with you at the first time, so I suggest you just check your container logs, if  your log is similar to the picture below, you could go to check if "/opt/cello" on your worker node is mounted correctly.

!cluster_createfail.png!;;;
column173: 29/Mar/19 11:09 AM;brendatian;The directory,  "/etc/hyperledger/fabric/msp/sigcerts" , is mapped to a directory under "/opt/cello", If "/opt/cello" is not mounted correctly, peer or orderer couldn't start because of lacking of that files.;;;

column178: 30/Mar/19 12:13 AM;arindambhattacharjee;Please provide the steps for mounting the directories with cello path;;;
column179:
01/Apr/19 11:25 AM;brendatian;# Had you checked if the "/opt/cello" is mounted using the method I described above ?
 # If the "/opt/cello" is not mounted, try to use " sudo mount -t nfs -o vers=4,loud ${MASTER_NODE}:/opt/cello" on your worker node to try to mount the directory and remember to replace ${MASTER_NODE} to your real master node ip.
 # If the command fails to execute, try to examine your os type:   1) install "nfs-common" if your os is ubuntu 2) install "nfs-utils" if your os is Centos or rethat
 # Then you can execute  " sudo mount -t nfs -o vers=4,loud ${MASTER_NODE}:/opt/cello" to try to mount again
 # Usually, the directory should  be mounted OK, you can check the content of the directory, it should be: !mount.png!

 ;;;

column1: Allow public gossip port to be set
column37: Currently ansible agent set the gossip port only to be the dns name, this is an issue when peers live multiple clouds. We need to improve the ansible agent to make sure that when it is needed the gossip port will be set to a public ip address and port.
column95: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Add doc on dashboard URL
column37: The dashboard needs to be accessed via the public IP, instead of local host.
column95: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Fix raft parameters in cello ansible agent
column37: Raft parameters have to be updated in configtx.j2 to support raft based ordering service in cello ansible agent
column95: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Update document for new user
column37: Cello has introduced an new API module for starting, need to update document to illustrate how to trigger it.
column95: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column37:

column1: Remove Fabric Base Image from Cello
column37:
At the end of Q3 2018 Fabric removed it dependency on the fabric-baseimage as the project had gotten out of scope and become a behemoth container used to support many things it was never intended to do.

The Fabric team will no longer be maintaining the Fabric Base Image repo and as such we are asking repos who use it to convert to using their own Ubuntu builds. At this point we are no longer updating the repo from within the Fabric team. Cello needs to gather its requirements and replace the image with its own internalized image.

column1: Master node would always be empty string when setup worker node with type docker
column37:
I am trying to setup a  docker worker node in cello. The worker node is in different machine with master node. 

So I follow the document [https://hyperledger-cello.readthedocs.io/en/latest/setup/setup_worker_docker/]

I installed docker, change the port to 2375, then I ran the command 

`MASTER_NODE=x.x.x.x WORKER_TYPE=docker make setup-worker`

but it always told me the `MASTER_NODE` is a empty string.

I found in the setup script `cello/scripts/worker_node/setup_worker_node_docker.sh` . Cello  always set `MASTER_NODE=""` which I believe is the reason.

step 2:  access the config file link

column1: Create new components for identity management and member management (from Justitia)
column37:
This feature adds two components "Cello-Identity" and "Cello-ConsortiumMember" to the cello.
 # Cello-identity
Create and manage identity (certificate and private key) in Cello independently into a separate component. Define some common interfaces in this component and implement them with fabric ca. In the database, we store the certificate and private key when the user needs to deploy a new node or use a new client User, the service can provide all the required certificates and private keys. This component can provide a CRL for updating the channel configuration when the certificate needs to invalidate the original certificate due to a private key leak or the like.
Users can also rewrite their implementation to suit their business based on specific needs.
 # Cello-ConsortiumMember
This component manages members of a federation or channel by submitting a channel configuration. The specific implementation uses the research results of the Fabric Interop Working Group, and proposes another alternative in the attachment[^Cello-ConsortiumMember alternative.pdf].
